question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
We know that a matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is not 0.

\[\begin{aligned} A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 2 & t+3 \\ 3 & 4 & t+1 \\ 2 & 2 & t+1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Then,

\[\begin{aligned} \det(A)&=\left| \begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 2 & t+3 \\ 3 & 4 & t+1 \\ 2 & 2 & t+1 \end{array}\right| \\ &= 3 \cdot 4 \cdot (t+1) + 2 \cdot (t+1) \cdot 2 + (t+3) \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \\ &\qquad - (t+3) \cdot 4 \cdot 2 - (t+1) \cdot 2 \cdot 3 - (t+1) \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \\ &= 12(t+1) + 4(t+1) + 6(t+3) \\ &\qquad - 8(t+3) - 6(t+1) - 6(t+1) \\ &= 4(t+1) - 2(t+3) \\ &= 2t-2\end{aligned}\]

Hence the determinant of the matrix A is zero if and only if t = 1. And so, the matrix is invertible for all values of t different than 1.

statement_html:
Determine the values of t for which the following matrix

\[\begin{aligned} A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 2 & t+3 \\ 3 & 4 & t+1 \\ 2 & 2 & t+1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

is invertible.
